title: How to Set up a Lan for Xbox

steps.title: Ensure you have a fast Internet connection.
steps.content: Ensure you have a fast Internet connection. Chances are, if you own an Xbox, which has sophisticated Internet capabilities, then you already have a fast connection.

steps.title: Decide how many Xboxes or computers you want to have in your system.
steps.content: Decide how many Xboxes or computers you want to have in your system. You will need to have them all set up in the same geographic area, most likely within the house. If you plan to keep the Xboxes in separate rooms, you will need long Ethernet cables. This LAN connection can work with both Xbox and Xbox 360.

steps.title: Hook each Xbox into the electrical outlet with a power cord.
steps.content: Hook each Xbox into the electrical outlet with a power cord. Then, hook each Xbox to a video cable so that it will play on the TV. You will need a TV and a copy of the video game you want to play for each Xbox you connect. Check on the back of the game jacket to see if the multi-player game supports Xbox system link.

steps.title: Acquire and plug in the LAN switch.
steps.content: Acquire and plug in the LAN switch. You can also use a router or a hub instead of a switch, if that is what you have on hand. However, a LAN switch with automatic uplink detection will be the easiest device to use when creating an Xbox LAN. Simply plug in your LAN switch to an electrical outlet.

steps.title: Find an Ethernet cable for each Xbox you want to hook up to your LAN.
steps.content: Find an Ethernet cable for each Xbox you want to hook up to your LAN. Each Xbox comes with a LAN port already built into the box. It is the place where you will connect 1 end of the Ethernet cable. You can find Ethernet patch cables at computer, video game and hardware stores, as well as on the Internet. Some people have extra Ethernet cables that were used to connect to the Internet before wireless connectivity was widespread. Get an Ethernet patch cable for any other computer device that you want to connect to your LAN, too.

steps.title: Press the end of the Ethernet cable into the LAN port on the Xbox.
steps.content: Press the end of the Ethernet cable into the LAN port on the Xbox. You should hear a click when the plastic cable connects. Repeat this with a separate Ethernet patch cable for each device.

steps.title: Plug the Ethernet cable into one of the 4-5 open ports on the back of the switch.
steps.content: Plug the Ethernet cable into one of the 4-5 open ports on the back of the switch. Just ensure you do not connect the Ethernet patch cable to the uplink port in another area of your switch device, because a different type of cable is used for this link. Connect the other end of each Ethernet patch cable to the LAN link for each device you plan to connect. Use the other ports next to the one you just connected.

steps.title: It can take several minutes for your devices to communicate with the Xbox.
steps.content: It can take several minutes for your devices to communicate with the Xbox. They should automatically set up a system link that you can scroll through your Xbox dashboard.

steps.title: Scroll through your system link to find the different devices that are connected.
steps.content: Scroll through your system link to find the different devices that are connected. Access these devices or put an Xbox multiplayer game into each console and begin playing.
